comments.body:
You’re right that dd-trace returns the literal `null`, it’s just that the opentracing API doesn’t actually accept `null` https://github.com/opentracing/opentracing-javascript/blob/0f145548a8c26f7761d33d274e5988e69ce2251e/src/tracer.ts#L14.

Having said that, I agree it seems cleaner to return literal `null` than `undefined`, so I’ll send a PR to opentracing instead, but it will probably take a while before it’s released and datadog uses it, so until then you’ll have to do `{ childOf: span ? span : undefined }`, which is a bit ugly.

Alternatively we can leave this typing as `undefined` for now and once the opentracing PR has been accepted, released, and in use in dd-trace, we can update this to specify `null` instead. What do you think?

Hmm, the opentracing source goes out of its way to delete the `childOf` key from the options object. On reflection, that’s probably because `undefined` values get left out when converted to JSON, so it seems like really dd-trace should return `undefined` instead.

```
> JSON.stringify({ foo: undefined, bar: null })
< "{\"bar\":null}"
```
Ah, okay. I'm fine leaving this as is.
(I’ll make that PR to dd-trace as part of some PRs I’m making anyways)
